sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Átila Fassina)
articles.description: Web Vitals are the new gold standard in performance due to their direct correlation with the user’s experience. In this article, you’ll learn what monitoring can do and how RayGun can help you sustain performance maintenance while scaling your app.
articles.title: How To Benchmark And Improve Web Vitals With Real User Metrics

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Leonardo Losoviz)
articles.description: If we want our WordPress plugins to offer a settings page that is fully powered by blocks, how can we do it? Since *Full Site Editing* doesn’t support this feature yet, we need to code a custom solution. In this article, we will learn how we can do it.
articles.title: Using The WordPress Editor And CPTs To Configure Plugins

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ilya Medvedev)
articles.description: How do text typing and editing work on the web? Although this process might seem straightforward, there is a lot of technical nuance behind its apparent simplicity. This article looks at how typing on the web works.
articles.title: How To Develop A Text Editor For The Web

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode, we’re talking about Responsible JavaScript. What does it mean for code to be responsible, and how should we approach projects differently? Drew McLellan talks to expert Jeremy Wagner to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 45 With Jeremy Wagner: What Is Responsible JavaScript?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ramona Schwering)
articles.description: You don’t need to be a full DevOps engineer if you want to introduce a testing build routine. With the help of some testing frameworks and GitHub actions, Ramona Schwering gives a short kick-off to help you get on the right track.
articles.title: Testing Pipeline 101 For Frontend Testing

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Knut Melvær)
articles.description: Markdown in all its flavors, interpretations, and forks won’t go away. However, it’s important to look at emerging content formats that try to encompass modern needs. In this article, Knut shares his advice against Markdown by looking back on why it was introduced in the first place, and by going through some of the major developments of content on the web.
articles.title: Thoughts On Markdown

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: We all need a little inspiration boost every now and again. In this post, we collected inspiring resources from all across the web for you — beautiful eye candy, tips to challenge your skills, and useful tools that are bound to spark new ideas. Enjoy!
articles.title: Falling In Love With The Web: Inspiring Websites And Tools

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Leonardo Losoviz)
articles.description: In this article, Leonardo Losoviz discusses some potential consequences as well as positive outcomes of WordPress joining the Block Protocol.
articles.title: Implications Of WordPress Joining The Block Protocol

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Nick Babich & Gleb Kuznetsov)
articles.description: Voice is a powerful tool that we can use to communicate with each other. This article covers the most critical aspects of designing for voice user interfaces: designing the conversation and designing visual interfaces.
articles.title: Everything You Want To Know About Creating Voice User Interfaces

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Frederick O’Brien)
articles.description: This installment of *Web Design Done Well* celebrates weird and wacky websites. Sites with sweet, innocent, sometimes pointless purposes. Are they money makers? Game changers? Not necessarily, but they sure are fun, and in ways only the web could really manage.
articles.title: Web Design Done Well: Perfectly Pointless

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Steven Hoober)
articles.description: In this article, Steven Hoober shines the spotlight on Fitts’ Law and explains why we should always ask questions and consider what particular guidelines and lessons mean to our users and our products.
articles.title: Fitts’ Law In The Touch Era

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sergey Melukov)
articles.description: Statoscope is an instrument that analyses your webpack-bundles. Created by Sergey Melukov, it started out as an experimental version in late 2016, which has now become a full-fledged toolkit for viewing, analyzing, and validating webpack-bundles.
articles.title: Statoscope: A Course Of Intensive Therapy For Your Bundle

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Stanislav Khrustalev)
articles.description: While QR codes have many uses and can be leveraged at many touch points, they are just one of dozens of technologies that can improve the customer’s journey. Stanislav Khrustalev shares his advice with a list of things to keep in mind when using QR codes for your business.
articles.title: Using QR Codes In Your Business: Best Practices And Pitfalls

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Noam Rosenthal)
articles.description: In this second part, Noam suggests a few patterns of how to use the web platform directly as an alternative to some of the solutions that are offered by frameworks.
articles.title: What Web Frameworks Solve: The Vanilla Alternative (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Michelle Barker)
articles.description: In this article, we’ll look specifically at what we can do to reduce the impact of social media embeds and social sharing widgets — or even some strategies to avoid them altogether. While the spotlight is on reducing the environmental impact, many of these tips will be great for performance too.
articles.title: Reducing The Web’s Carbon Footprint: Optimizing Social Media Embeds

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: In this article, Adrian Bece shares more about the benefits and caveats of code-splitting and how page performance and load times can be improved by dynamically loading expensive, non-critical JavaScript bundles.
articles.title: Improving JavaScript Bundle Performance With Code-Splitting

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: It’s shipping! Meet “Touch Design for Mobile Interfaces”, our brand-new guide with guidelines and best practices to improve usability and accessibility on mobile. 400 pages. For designers and developers working with mobile UIs.
articles.title: Meet “Touch Design For Mobile Interfaces”, A New Smashing Book

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Do you need a little inspiration boost? Well, then our new batch of desktop wallpapers is for you. Designed by artists and designers from across the globe, they come in versions with and without a calendar for February 2022.
articles.title: 28 Days Of Inspiration (February 2022 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Noam Rosenthal)
articles.description: In this article, Noam Rosenthal dives deep into a few technical features that are common across frameworks, and explains how some of the different frameworks implement them and what they cost.
articles.title: What Web Frameworks Solve And How To Do Without Them (Part 1)

articles.author: Temani Afif
articles.description: It's always cool to have a fancy section divider on your website. And it's even better if we can make them responsive and easy to adjust. This is what you will learn in this article. We will explore different section dividers made using only CSS and some optimized code that's
articles.title: How to Create a Section Divider Using CSS

articles.author: Dionysia Lemonaki
articles.description: In this article you will learn how to find the index of an element contained in a list in the Python programming language. There are a few ways to achieve this, and in this article you will learn three of the different techniques used to find the index of a
articles.title: Python Find in List – How to Find the Index of an Item or Element in a List

articles.author: Kolade Chris
articles.description: In programming languages, getting the length of a particular data type is a common practice. Python is no different because you can use the built-in len() function to get the length of a string, tuple, list, dictionary, or any other data type. In this article, I'm going to show you
articles.title: What is len() in Python? How to Use the len() Function to Find the Length of a String

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: Flutter is an open-source UI software development kit used to create cross-platform applications for iOS, Android, Windows, Mac, and more. We just published a 37-hour Flutter course for beginners on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel. Vandad Nahavandipoor developed this course. Vlandad is a Google Developer Expert and Lead iOS Developer. Flutter
